I recommend it if you don't want to deal with a story and go straight into the action.  Lots of upgrades and procedurally generated missions add a lot to the replay value.

Early Access Review

A fast, fun, Arcade Style flight shoot 'em up!

I've always been a huge Flight Sim fan, so I tend to judge these games strongly.  (Looking at you, Assault Horizon and JASF).  My benchmark, usually is the Ace Combat series.  (Specifically '5: The Unsung War'.)  But Sky Rogue doesn't really make that a fair comparison.  It feels more like Ace Combat mixed with a bit of After Burner, because of the general fast pace of gameplay.

Overall, I'm very impressed with this game.  Works great with a Gamepad.  Controls are responsive, and the minimalist graphics give the game a very sharp and clean look.  The Dogfighting feels deliciously visceral, the Weapons are all useful in some way, there are a load of Aircraft available, and the AI is quite challenging.

My only real criticism at this point is the control scheme.  Generally, in most Flight Games, Guns and Missiles/Bombs are bound to two seperate buttons, because Missiles/Bombs are generally 'Primary' Weapons, while Guns are more 'Secondary' Weapons.  In Sky Rogue, all Weapons are bound to a single button, and are swapped between using another button.  This makes it awkward to switch between Guns and Missiles.  I'd recommend to the developers to adopt a system similar to the one I mentioned.

I give this game a good thumbs up! :D

The game's strength lies in its tight control scheme. Controls are responsive; your sci-fi jet fighter, obedient. Those who have played Ace Combat will feel instant familiarity, though the traditional button to change targets in AC is, in Sky Rogue, the button to swap weapons. I suffered several rounds of accidentally cycling through my weapons before I had the good sense to change the key bindings on my 360 gamepad. Chasing down enemy fighters, dodging missiles, and swerving out of the way of enemy AWACS tumbling out of the sky is a treat, particularly for those of us longing for Namco to revive the AC franchise.

There are some downsides that make Sky Rogue tough to recommend. For one, you're locked into a single, uninteresting map. After a few rounds, I was desperate for something—ANYTHING—different than green clumps surrounded by blue water. Second, the music. Rather, the song. There is a single tune that accompanies you in the air, a chiptune throwback to the SNES era. It's highly reminisicent of a Starfox tune, and while it starts out catchy it soon becomes irksomely repetitive.

Last, and most important, is the unfortunate fact that most the mission objectives are a chore. If the game is feeling charitable, it might throw a couple AWACS planes your way. Chasing down the AWACS and their fighter escorts is fast and tense—one might forget they weren't playing Ace Combat for a minute. From Day 3 onwards, these ground objectives are surrounded by long-range SAM sites, making carpet bombing from above the ideal tactic. reviewText:
Early Access Review

Sky Rogue is a distillation of the combat flight sim genre, whittling it down to its action-packed essence. This is not a game about realism or technical complexity, nor about peaceful and lengthy flights. It bears far more resemblance to StarFox or classic Top Gun games than to DCS or Falcon BMS. You will be fighting enemies the minute you're off the deck, often in overwhelming numbers. Ammunition recharges, and planes can pull of maneuvers a MiG pilot could only dream of. But there is balance in Sky Rogue's simplicity. It packs in arcade-y style to make it fun to just pick up and play, but it retains just enough realism to make you feel like you're actually flying. The planes are more maneuverable than some real-life aircraft, but you do still have to think about stalling, gravity, and how your speed is affecting your turn rate. Ammunition regenerates, but weapons have limitations like radar cones. Everything, whether flying, shooting, or dodging enemy fire, has a nice visceral feel to it.

Sky Rogue is the perfect pick-up-and-play combat flight sim. There's enough complexity of systems and skill required to give it longevity, but you won't need to watch a 4-hour tutorial just to be able to play the game. And you won't need to devote an hour to playing at a stretch. You can pick it up and play it for however long you want, be that 5 minutes or 5 hours.

Cons:

Things like destroyed aircraft still being physical objects you can crash into and die as a result of, escalating threat level as you blow stuff up, both sky and land targets, the simple yet dynamic flight controls, the simple but engaging music, solid 60fps framerate by the looks of things, wonderful way of levelling up and unlocking stuff...

SPLIT.
SCREEN.
MULTIPLAYER.

oh yeah you like that? Course you do. Ace Combat classic action style right there.

Get this right now. You won't regret it. I paid £6.29 for this. I would have gladly paid £10 for this, MINIMUM. I could easily pay up to £15 for this and still feel it was absolutely 100% worth it.

Honestly I think the only downside is that they're selling this game short!

So in summary, do you like games like Afterburner, StarFox/Starwing, and Ace Combat? Then you will absolutely adore this game. And you should get it. It's ridiculously cheap even at full price.

[edit] Oh goddammit I keep loving this game. I cannot stop playing it. I seriously adore it! it was awesome when it was free and it's even more awesome now that it's not free.

[UPDATE 8/1/16] Yes, this game is still very highly recommended. Yes it's still bloody incredible, yes you should still buy this game. The pricetag is relatively tiny, the framerate is blistering, the action is still hot and hard, the modding support is getting better as time goes on, the ability to upgrade your weapons too adds more to the game, and theres more stuff to spend your scrap on now as a result. :D Every update makes the game even better than before!

I purchased this game a fair while back when it was on Itch.io, and I'm so happy I did! I enjoy flying games but often I find the really hardcore sims are just too much for me (DCS, Falcon, etc.). As such, it's nice having this more accessible game, but what really impresses me about the design is how it still manages to convey so much of what makes modern air combat interesting in such an easy-to-play package.

There are numerous types of aircraft, all of which handle significantly differently from each other. Add on top of that you can load out the different planes with different weaponry (but you can't overload your airframes maximum payload!).

The game procedurally generates islands for you to conduct your air war, and each island poses a different challenge that can be completed in multiple ways. If your target is a ground structure, do you want to destroy the enemy carrier so you won't be harassed by enemy aircraft and can bomb with impunity? Or do you want try to get a fast plane to dodge enemy fire and zip in-and-out of range before they can catch up?

The developer is very active and responsive, and I'd imagine this game will expand in some very interesting directions. But frankly, even if it doesn't, it's well worth the money for the accessible-yet-deep air combat you'll experience with the game as-is.

Early Access Review

Day 1: Snore through an easy mission.

Day 3: Enjoy a fun arcade flight sim with a good variety of planes and weapons and an occasionally finicky lock-on system.

Day 5: Launch off the deck of your helicarrier into an unbreaking stream of homing missiles and die. Start over.


The real tragedy of the obnoxious difficulty curve is that it presses the player into a more narrow choice of play-styles than the game would seem to otherwise allow. There are ground attack missions, but don't try making a low-altitude loadout based on rockets or cannons because enemy fighters and SAMS will vaporize you. The only way to survive ground attack missions is to drop bombs on your target from a mile away and flee back to your carrier before more fighters spawn. Those giant long-range interceptor missiles look cool, but don't ever use them because enemy fighters turn on a dime and dodge them every time. Even dogfights are reduced to nothing but an endless turning battle with stupidly maneuverable enemies while you mash the button that deploys your (finite) countermeasures to deflect their (infinite) missiles. Half the planes go unused because they can't survive the world the game generates. It's frustrating, but more importantly it's monotonous.

I'm thinking the flight sim format doesn't blend well with roguelike elements like procedural generation and permadeath. The game gives you the tools of a traditional flight sim but they're the wrong tools to deal with the challenges of a roguelike.

Early Access Review

It took me about 15 minutes to fall in love with Sky Rogue. This game scratches an itch that many other flight combat sims do not, and allows you to enjoy the thrill of flight and aerial combat without the immense frustration of repeating a difficult failed mission over and over to progress. If you fail, you are simply given a new series of missions, procedurally generated missions with objectives that you must bomb off the face of the earth or shoot out of the sky. Each mission also presents numerous optional objectives which you can destroy for additional credit towards unlocking the next tech, which can be new aircraft, weapons, or utility items like afterburners and IR flares.

This game is rather reminiscent of the sleeper gem Starfighter for 3D0, which had similar graphics and open-world objectives (and many other remarkable features).

Visually the game is appealingly simple, flat vector graphics with striking aircraft designs featuring pleasant details and moving parts that react to your control of the craft, such as a swing-wing interceptor that changes configuration as you accelerate.

The controls are smooth using a gamepad.

Did I mention it has local co-op with splitscreen?

I bought three games the other day, this one was the cheapest and also completely dominated my attention out of the three. Highly recommended if you like to be a Top Gun. It's lovely, challenging and fun. Can't remember the last flight game that kept me coming back for more.
